title: Ticket #5002: MOUNT_UNDER_SCRATCH should have access to the job ad
description: The configuration variable MOUNT_UNDER_SCRATCH should (optionally) be allowed to be a classad expression instead of a simple list of directories. If it is an expression, the it should be evaluated in the context of a job ad, the result of the evaluation should be a string that the starter will use as a list of directories.
remarks:
2015-Apr-13 19:49:41 by bbockelm:
Todd and I had discussed this a few weeks back. A few thoughts that came up since then:
  • Traditionally in Unix, allowing users to muck around with filesystem mounts is considered a security bug (as they can fool setuid binaries -- think of what fun could be had if the user could overwrite /etc/sudoers.d). How can we validate this is a safe action?
    • Linux's solution to this was PR_SET_NO_NEW_PRIVS (see #4443)
  • Is there a way to add this without introducing a new config knob? I couldn't think of any...

2015-Apr-14 10:29:05 by johnkn:
The proposed implementation does not allow the job to set mounts directly. but a badly written STARTD config could potentially allow them to.

We were thinking that the use case is something like this. 

    MOUNT_UNDER_SCRATCH = IfThenElse(Owner=?="Special", "/tmp", "/tmp,/mnt/shared")

to deny non-special jobs access to the shared filesystem.

2015-Apr-14 14:25:42 by johnkn:
After some discussion with ZKM, we have decided to go forward with the current design. It's true that a sloppy STARTD configuration could result in jobs injecting mount points, but we don't anticipate that normal use of the feature will pose any risk.
